metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Police, Bombay v. Respondent (Detenue)

facts.text: Respondent first arrested on 18th December 1948 under Bombay Public Security Measures Act, 1948 (Bombay Act IV of 1947), released on 11th November 1949.
Respondent arrested again on 21st April 1950 under Preventive Detention Act, 1950.
On 29th April 1950, grounds for detention supplied: 'That you are engaged and are likely to be engaged in promoting acts of sabotage on railway and railway property in Greater Bombay.'

Respondent filed habeas corpus petition on 31st July 1950, contending grounds vague, no particulars of when/where/what sabotage, mala fide to detain trade unionists of All-India Trade Union Congress, stayed out of Bombay after release in Ratlam and Delhi, returned 20th April 1950.
On 9th August 1950, High Court directed issue of notice to Commissioner of Police, rule pending disposal.
On 26th August 1950, Commissioner sent further particulars under section 7: activities in Greater Bombay between January 1950 and date of detention, likely to continue.

On 30th August 1950, Commissioner filed affidavit: objectionable activities Jan 1950 to detention, promoting railway strike in March 1950 via sabotage in Greater Bombay, reliable materials from police, strike did not materialise but intent continued, denial respondent out of Bombay post Nov 1949, was in Bombay major part.
Bombay High Court on 1st September 1950 granted petition, ordered release, holding initial grounds vague, cannot amplify later, violation of Art 22(5).
Appeal to Supreme Court under Art 132 Constitution.

legal_issues.text: Whether the initial grounds supplied on 29th April 1950 were vague and insufficient to enable representation under Art 22(5).
Whether detaining authority can supply further particulars or supplemental facts after initial grounds, without violating Art 22(5).
Scope of Art 22(5): rights to grounds and representation, justiciability of sufficiency of grounds for representation.

petitioner_arguments.text: Grounds not vague if rationally connected to objects in s.3; subjective satisfaction of government not challengeable except mala fides; can supply further particulars if not new grounds.
Later communication on 26 Aug valid as particulars of existing grounds, not new; High Court erred in rejecting it solely because after initial grounds.

respondent_arguments.text: Grounds vague, no particulars of when/where/how sabotage; mala fide to detain trade unionists; out of Bombay post-release till arrest.
Cannot amplify/improve grounds later; must judge on 29 Apr grounds; violation of fundamental right.

court_reasoning.text: Grounds are conclusions from facts indicating prejudicial acts; must supply grounds as existed at order, no addition; but can supply further facts/ particulars supporting same grounds if not new conclusions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Second communication valid if facts already considered in initial ground, not new ground.

court_reasoning.text: Vagueness test for satisfaction (subjective, not justiciable except mala fides/relevancy) different from vagueness for enabling representation (justiciable).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Two distinct rights in Art 22(5): furnish grounds (as soon as may be), afford earliest opportunity for representation (may require particulars).

court_reasoning.text: Initial ground had rational connection to s.3 objects; later particulars related to same period/activities; High Court erred in holding no later communication permissible.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Detention valid; petition should be dismissed.

court_reasoning.text: Patanjali Sastri J: Courts cannot examine sufficiency of grounds for representation; subjective satisfaction; Art 22(6) allows withholding facts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No judicial review of sufficiency for representation.

court_reasoning.text: Das J: Order valid if subjective satisfaction on relevant grounds; communication of vague grounds does not invalidate if not mala fides; no requirement for precise particulars.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Vagueness not justiciable for representation unless bad faith.

holdings.text: Detaining authority must communicate grounds (conclusions) as soon as may be; can provide further facts/particulars later if supporting same grounds, without violating Art 22(5), provided earliest opportunity for representation.
Sufficiency of grounds to enable representation is justiciable, but distinct from sufficiency for government's subjective satisfaction.
In this case, initial grounds sufficient; later particulars valid; detention lawful.

precedents_cited.case_name: A.K. Gopalan v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Art 21 applies to preventive detention subject to Art 22; s.3 valid, subjective satisfaction.
Preventive detention based on suspicion; court not appropriate to investigate.
Privilege against disclosure supports subjective interpretation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Machindar Shivaji Mahar v. The King
precedents_cited.relevance: Subjective satisfaction; court examines relevancy, not sufficiency.
Prima facie vagueness led to release, but no arguments heard.

statutes_cited.name: Preventive Detention Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Order on subjective satisfaction to prevent prejudicial acts; communicate grounds, afford representation.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Procedure established by law; safeguards for preventive detention; appeal jurisdiction.

statutes_cited.name: Criminal Procedure Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Habeas corpus referenced by High Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside Bombay High Court order releasing the respondent, held detention valid as initial grounds complied with Art 22(5) and later particulars permissible, dismissed habeas corpus petition.

key_quotes.text: "The grounds being the heads, from which the Government was satisfied that it was necessary to pass the order of detention, there can be no addition to those grounds."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines grounds as existing conclusions; no new grounds later.

key_quotes.text: "If the later communication contains facts leading to a conclusion which is outside the ground first supplied, the same cannot be looked into as supporting the order of detention."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Test for validity of supplemental communications.

key_quotes.text: "It is not for the court to sit in the place of the Central Government or the State Government and try to determine if it would have come to the same conclusion."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The combined effect of clauses (5) and (6) is... to require the detaining authority to communicate... only such particulars as that authority and not a court of law, considers sufficient."
key_quotes.speaker: Patanjali Sastri J.
key_quotes.significance: No judicial review of sufficiency for representation.
